extendedIngredients.name: canned tomatoes
extendedIngredients.original: 1 (28-ounce) can crushed or pureed Italian tomatoes (recommended: San Marzano)
extendedIngredients.originalName: crushed or pureed Italian tomatoes (recommended: San Marzano)

extendedIngredients.name: carrot
extendedIngredients.original: 1 medium carrot, peeled and chopped into 1/2-inch pieces
extendedIngredients.originalName: carrot, peeled and chopped into 1/2-inch pieces

extendedIngredients.name: olive oil
extendedIngredients.original: 1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus extra for drizzling
extendedIngredients.originalName: extra-virgin olive oil, plus extra for drizzling

extendedIngredients.name: olive oil
extendedIngredients.original: Olive oil, for drizzling, plus 3 tablespoons
extendedIngredients.originalName: Olive oil, for drizzling, plus 3 tablespoons

extendedIngredients.name: red pepper flakes
extendedIngredients.original: 1/2 teaspoon red pepper flakes, plus extra for garnish
extendedIngredients.originalName: red pepper flakes, plus extra for garnish

extendedIngredients.name: rustic bread
extendedIngredients.original: 1 (1-pound) loaf ciabatta or rustic bread, trimmed and cut into 3/4-inch thick slices
extendedIngredients.originalName: ciabatta or rustic bread, trimmed and cut into 3/4-inch thick slices

extendedIngredients.name: white wine
extendedIngredients.original: 3/4 cup white wine, such as Pinot Grigio
extendedIngredients.originalName: white wine, such as Pinot Grigio

extendedIngredients.name: arctic char
extendedIngredients.original: 1 1/2 pounds whitefish fillets, halibut, cod or arctic char, skinned and cut into 3/4-inch chunks
extendedIngredients.originalName: whitefish fillets, halibut, cod or arctic char, skinned and cut into 3/4-inch chunks

title: Ligurian Fish Stew
summary: Ligurian Fish Stew requires about 1 hour and 17 minutes from start to finish. This recipe makes 6 servings with 734 calories, 9g of protein, and 53g of fat each. For $1.55 per serving, this recipe covers 16% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. It can be enjoyed any time, but it is especially good for Autumn. It is brought to you by Foodnetwork. It works well as a reasonably priced soup. If you have wine, rustic bread, garlic clove, and a few other ingredients on hand, you can make it. 71 person have made this recipe and would make it again. It is a good option if you're following a vegan diet. Overall, this recipe earns a solid spoonacular score of 51%. Try Ligurian Buridda (Italian Fish Stew), Ligurian Seafood Stew, and Easy Fish Molee (South Indian-Style Fish Stew With Coconut) for similar recipes.
instructions: For the stew: In a 6-quart, heavy bottomed stock pot or Dutch oven, heat 1/3 cup of oil over medium-high heat. Add the carrot, onion, and garlic. Season with salt and cook, stirring frequently, until the vegetables begin to soften, about 5 to 8 minutes. Turn the heat to high. Add the wine and scrape up the brown bits that cling to the bottom of the pan with a wooden spoon. Cook until most of the liquid has evaporated, about 5 minutes. Add the tomatoes, water and red pepper flakes. Reduce the heat and bring the mixture to a simmer. Cover and cook until the vegetables are tender, about 18 to 20 minutes. Season the fish with salt and add to the stew. Cook, stirring occasionally, until cooked through, about 5 to 8 minutes. Season the stew with salt, if needed.                          For the Crostini: Put an oven rack in the center of the oven and preheat the oven to 375 degrees F.                          Arrange the bread slices in a single layer on a baking sheet and drizzle with olive oil. Bake until light golden, about 12 minutes. Cool for 2 minutes. Rub the warm toasts with the cut side of the garlic.                          Ladle the stew into serving bowls and garnish with parsley. Drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle a few red pepper flakes on top. Serve with the crostini.

steps.step: For the stew: In a 6-quart, heavy bottomed stock pot or Dutch oven, heat 1/3 cup of oil over medium-high heat.
Add the carrot, onion, and garlic. Season with salt and cook, stirring frequently, until the vegetables begin to soften, about 5 to 8 minutes. Turn the heat to high.
Add the wine and scrape up the brown bits that cling to the bottom of the pan with a wooden spoon. Cook until most of the liquid has evaporated, about 5 minutes.

Add the tomatoes, water and red pepper flakes. Reduce the heat and bring the mixture to a simmer. Cover and cook until the vegetables are tender, about 18 to 20 minutes. Season the fish with salt and add to the stew. Cook, stirring occasionally, until cooked through, about 5 to 8 minutes. Season the stew with salt, if needed.
For the Crostini: Put an oven rack in the center of the oven and preheat the oven to 375 degrees F.
Arrange the bread slices in a single layer on a baking sheet and drizzle with olive oil.
Bake until light golden, about 12 minutes. Cool for 2 minutes. Rub the warm toasts with the cut side of the garlic.
Ladle the stew into serving bowls and garnish with parsley.
Drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle a few red pepper flakes on top.
